avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche danger is assessed as moderate above 1,800 metres and low below that. Slab avalanches can be triggered in some places even with little additional load and can reach medium size when breaking through the persistent weak layer. The danger areas are located in particular in the north-west to east aspects behind ridgelines and terrain edges as well as in the entrance areas to steep gullies and bowls. In particular, transitions from a little to a lot of snow and the edges of fresh and older snow packs should be avoided.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Beware of prone to triggering persistent weak layers in the high altitudes!

snowpackStructure.comment: At high altitudes, fresh and older wind slab snow lies in the extended north and east exposures on an unstable snow cover, snowpack with weak layers of faceted crystals and floating snow. Fresh and older drift snow packs form the snow slab on the existing weak layers and are prone to triggering. On the sunny slopes, the snow cover, snowpack is mostly settled and quite compact. On the sunny slopes, the slopes in some regions are bare up to 2000 metres.

tendency.highlights: No change in avalanche danger. Partly strong southerly winds in dry air. No snow in sight at the moment!

weatherForecast.comment: Monday night will be clear and cloudless. There may still be fog in the valleys on Monday, especially in the morning, but outside the fog the air will be very dry and visibility will be good. What remains is the sometimes strong southerly wind, which will reach gale force at times, especially from the Eisenerz Alps to the Hochschwab. At an altitude of 2000 metres, it's between -4 degrees in the southern Niedere Tauern and -1 degree in the Ennstal Alps.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche danger is assessed as low. Slab avalanches can still be triggered in a few places with little additional load, but usually remain small. The danger areas are located in particular in the north-west to east aspects behind ridgelines and terrain edges as well as in the entrance areas to steep gullies and bowls. Prone to triggering is greatest at the transition from a little to a lot of snow and in the edge areas of fresh and older snow packs.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Areas prone to triggering due to weak layers in the persistent weak layer

snowpackStructure.comment: At high altitudes, fresh and older wind slab snow lies in the extended northern and eastern exposures on an unstable snow cover, snowpack with weak layers of faceted crystals and floating snow.  Snowdrift accumulations form the snow slab on the existing weak layers and are sometimes prone to disruption. On the sunny slopes, the snow cover, snowpack is mostly settled and quite compact. The snow depths are still below average.

tendency.highlights: No change in avalanche danger. Partly strong southerly winds in dry air. No snow in sight at the moment!

weatherForecast.comment: Monday night will be clear and cloudless. On Monday, there may still be fog in the valleys, especially in the morning; outside the fog, the air will be very dry and visibility will be correspondingly good. A moderate to brisk, cold southerly wind will blow on the mountains. Temperatures at 2000 metres are around -4 degrees.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche danger is low. In extremely steep and shady slopes above the tree line, the triggering of small slab avalanches cannot be completely ruled out. The risk of injury and falling generally outweighs the risk of burial. In general, be careful in the hardness or icy entrance areas to steep gullies. Especially in the extended northern exposures, fresh, thin snowdrift accumulations can cover the icy areas.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Low avalanche danger, isolated avalanche prone locations in shady slopes

snowpackStructure.comment: The snow surface is crusted and hard, during the day it hardly softens even on the sunny slopes. The snow base, fundament is usually set and compact. In extremely steep shady-slope gullies, the snow base, fundament can be partially weakened by angular shapes, but these areas are rare. In general, the snow cover is below average, with often only a few centimetres of snow covering the ground below the tree line.

tendency.highlights: No change in avalanche danger. Partly strong southerly winds in dry air. No snow in sight at the moment!

weatherForecast.comment: The sun shines all day from a cloudless sky. Local patches of fog on the eastern edge of the Alps and south of the Graz mountains will reach up to around 500 metres above sea level. The high wind will blow brisk to strong and icy cold from south-east to south. Temperatures at 1500 metres above sea level are around -4 degrees.

ALBINA.generalHeadline: Beware of persistent weak layer problems in steep terrain
